Linux Privilege Escalation

This Lab covers different ways to escalate privilege on Linux Systems.

LAB LINK: Linux Privilege Escalation

LAB difficulty: Medium

Published on August 02, 2024 by Jose Luis Venega

LAB

Privilege escalation consists of exploiting a system vulnerability to gain unauthorized access from a low-privilege account to one with higher privileges e.g root account (this one has all the permissions in the system)

Through these processes, we can perform several tasks such as:

  • Resetting passwords.
  • Bypassing protected data access control.
  • Enabling persistence.
  • Modifying system configuration.
  • Changing users privilege.

Enumeration

Enumeration is the first step to gaining access to any system. As we mentioned earlier, by exploring a critical system vulnerability, we can gain access to a high-privilege account or even an superuser account (root). To archive this, we should know about several enumeration methods.

Hostname

The hostname command returns the name of out target machine, which can sometimes provides useful information to understand the role of the machine within the network.

Uname -a

With the uname -a command, we can display additional information about the kernel the system is using. This is very useful for finding kernel-level vulnerabilities, in order to escalate privileges.

/proc/version

If we look in the /proc/version directory, we can see the kernel version and additional data, and the filesystem proc (procfs) provides information about the processes on the target system.

/etc/issue

The system can also be identified by consulting the /etc/issue file, which contains information about the O.S but this can easily be customized or changed.

Ps & pspy commands

The ps command show us all the processes running on the Linux system, where the following is displayed:

  • PID: Process ID.
  • TTY: Type of terminal used.
  • Time: Amount of CPU usage time.
  • CMD: Command or executable that is running.

This command offers several options such as ps -A, where we see all processes or ps aux, where it shows all processes of all users (a), the command that launches (u), and shows processes that are not linked to the terminal (x).

By seeing the output of the ps command, we can better understand the system and possible vulnerabilities in it.

However, the ps may not show us some of the desired processes, so we will make use of the pspy command.

Env command

The env command displays the environmental variables:

The variable *PATH* is the path used by the shell to execute commands and executables (without having to specify the path), if we alter in our favour, we will be able to access files without having the necessary privileges to do it in a normal way.

Sudo-l command

With the sudo -l command we can list the commands that the user can use to become the root user, i.e. list of the commands that the user can execute using sudo.

This does not implies that they are always executed as root, but the can give permissions to execute files such as www-data.

Ls command

The ls command allows us to list files and directories, it is one of the most common, but when it comes to privilege escalation it is very useful as it can help us to find hidden files or directories, this can be done with ls -la command.

In this example we see how using ls shows us nothing, but if we use ls -la we find a files called secret.txt.

Id command

With this command, we can obtain information about the privilege level of a group of users or the user.

/etc/passwd

In the directory file /etc/passwd we will find all system users.

If we do a cat /etc/passwd we will get as output:

We can make it more readable and use it as a list for brute force attacks by doing cat /etc/passwd | cut -d ":" -f 1, where we cut from “:” and only keep the first column:

History command

If we type history in the terminal, it will return the inputs that have been previously typed in the terminal, here we can find privilege information.

Ifconfig command

It may be that our target machine is pivoting to another network, so by using ifconfig command, we can see information about the machine`s network interfaces.

Netstat command

With netstat -a we can check the existing network interfaces and routes of a certain machine, using the netstat -a command we can see all the opening ports and established connections, with netstat -at (TCP connections),netstat -au (UDP connections) and with nestat -l we list the ports that are in listening mode.

With nestat -s we list the network usage statistics for each protocol, and we can specify the protocol using -t (TCP) or -u (UDP).

Find command

This command is very useful for searching binaries with the SUID bit set, which can be executed by the user in order to escalate privileges. We can use 2>/dev/null to redirect the errors to /dev/null and only displays the result without errors.

To perform a search, it would be → find / -type f -name <filename> 2>/dev/null, with the option -type f we are searching files with a specific name starting from the root directory </code>/</code>.

As we mentioned earlier, we can use find to search binaries with the SUID bit set to escalate privileges. For this, we would use find / -perm -4000 2>/dev/null or find / -perm -4000 -type f -exec ls -ld {} \; 2>/dev/null, where for each file it finds, it will execute the ls -ld command, where {} is replaced by the name of each file and \; marks the end of the -exec command.

This second search is more complete because it can help us find the binary to execute the vulnerability.

Privilege Escalation: Linux Kernel Exploits

The Linux kernel manage the communications between various components such as system memory, apps and so on..

Any of these functions must have sufficient permissions to be carried out, so exploiting such a vulnerability will grant root permissions.

The methodology to follow is:

  1. Identify the kernel version.
  2. Search and find an exploit for that kernel version
  3. Execute the exploit.

Although this seems very simple, if the kernel fails, a system crash will occur.

Practical example:

To identify the Linux system kernel, we will use the following command → uname -a:

After the name wade7363, we find the system kernel version, if we search on Google for any CVE related to that kernel version, we find → Exploit-DB

Here we find a script which allows us to exploit the system kernel, to do this:

First of all, we navigate to the directory /tmp of our machine → cd /tmp and we create a new file with a “.c” extension → touch exploit.c.

Next, we copy the exploit code and paste it into our file created with touch.

Using the command python3 -m http.server 8080, we create a server, and on the target machine we use the command wget:

The connection is made and the file is downloaded to the target machine.

Now, we switch to the directory /tmp on the target machine and use wget

Now, we compile the script with gcc filename.c -o filename and we execute it using ./filename

In this case, it will be:

We proceed to compile the file:

We can see that we have an executable and the file with the extension “.c”

Now, with ./exploit we execute the exploit.

We can see, we`ve already scaled privileges as root, and now we are able to do whatever we want in the system.

Escalate Privileges: Sudo

By default, sudo command allows us to run programs and commands as root level.

As we have seen above, using sudo -l command we can list every command that the user can run as root.

To take advantage of this, we can search on internet GTFOBins some exploits of certain commands which we have execution permissions.

In real life, not everything is in GTObins and ExploitDB, so a potential solution could be to look for another ways such as:

  1. Verify Sudo settings → Sometimes this configuration "/etc/sudoers" is not correct allowing to unauthorized users to execute commands as root without password.
  2. Exploiting Software vulnerabilities → It may be the case that the system have vulnerable software installed, this software can be exploited to escalate privilege.

Practical Example:

We have this machine, using sudo -l we can see all the commands that the user can execute as sudo. In this case, the user karen can execute the following commands or binaries.

We can use any of these 3 commands (find, less or nano). In our example we choose /usr/bin/find.

Now, we look in GTFOBins - SUDO for some information about how to exploit this binary.

We found the following command:

Bash 
find . -exec /bin/sh \; -quit

Finally, we have escalated privileges as root.

Privilege Escalation: SUID

As we have seen above, using find / -perm -4000 -type f -exec ls -ld{} \; 2>/dev/null command, we can find out which binaries have the SUID bit set, this is another way of trying to escalate privileges.

Depending on the binary, we can either become root users or execute commands that require root permissions, but without the current user having them (we can see that in the practical example).

After having carried out the search, we can search in GTFOBins exploits depending on the binary to exploit, for example in the practical example we see we have the following binary /usr/bin/base64, so we will look for the base64 SUID bit exploit on that website.

Practical Example:

For example, if we find the base64 binary with SUID bit set, we can do use its exploit to access files which require root permissions such as /etc/passwd (system users) or /etc/shadow(system passwords).

In the following website GTFOBins, we found base64 SUID bit exploit and if we execute LFILE =file_to_read and then ./base64 "$LFILE" | base64 --decode we can open both files (by specifying them in file_to_read) without having root permissions.

Content of /etc/shadow command:

Content of /etc/passwd command:

Through this, in our machine we can create two new files called, for example, users.txt (content from /etc/passwd) and passwords.txt (content from /etc/shadow), and we can sent them to a new file to decrypt the passwords:

Now, we are going to decrypt them using JohnTheRipper by making use of a wordlist called (rockyou.txt):

As a result we got the password:

Privilege Escalation: Capabilities

Another method that system administrators can use to escalate privilege of a process or binary is “Capabilities”. These help us to manage specific permissions for applications so they can execute without needing to grant them all permissions.

Bash 
getcap -r / 2>/dev/null

If we come across any programming language, we can investigate to escalate privileges. Therefore, if this happens, we go again GTFOBins to search for exploits in the Capabilities section.

If we make use of previous command, we are going to list the System Capabilities and, for example we find:

We found that 6 binaries have the Capabilities set, the most interesting one are /home/karen/vim and /home/ubuntu/view.

As our flag is located in /home/ubuntu and we are not able to access it because the flag needs root permissions, we will have to find a way to access the file.

On GTFObins - Capabilities we can search information about the binary to exploit in order to access the flag. But if we use the command /home/ubuntu/view /home/ubuntu/flag4.txt, we gain access to the flag by exploiting the binary /home/ubuntu/view without needing become root users.

We can make use of any binary with the Capabilities set to access to the flag file.

Example with view binary:
Example with vim binary:

Privilege Escalation: Cron Jobs

Cron Jobs are using to execute binaries or scripts at specific times. By default, they run with the privilege of their owners and not the current user.

Thanks to this, if we find a scheduled task with root privileges and we can change the script that will be run, then our script will run with root privileges.

Through the command cat /etc/crontab, we can see all the schedule cron jobs on the system, but there may be tasks that cannot be read through cron. For that, we can make use of the pspy command.

This escalation of privileges is done through a reverse shell, so the file to modify will be a .sh file, where we will overwrite its content with the reverse shell code.

Practical Example:

We have a target machine. As we have seen above, by using the command cat /etc/crontab, we can see commands and executables that are scheduled.

If we look closely, we find a file called /home/karen/backup.sh, this one has root permissions. To escalate privileges in this way, we need to modify this file and turn it into a reverse shell.

On RevShells we can generate the reverse shell that we will use, to do this we have to know our public IP → ifconfig → tun0 and the type of the reverse shell should be Bash.

We include in the file [backup.sh]the reverse shell using nano .

Now, we give it execution permissions:

Next, we see that the reverse shell has been produced and we are inside as root user.

Privilege Escalation: PATH Hijacking

Commands in Linux Systems are executed from left to right, so if we drop a malicious file in that path, it will be execute without any problem.

If we run echo $PATH, we obtain the path that the system follows to search executables or scripts, i.e, the system look for these executables without having to specify the whole path.

For this, we do:

  1. We create a new file with C programming language extension ".c" → touch filename.c
  2. Next, we introduce the malicious code, setting both suid and sgid to 0.
C 
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
int main(){
  setuid(0); //Set user ID to 0 (root).
  setgid(0); //Set group ID to 0 (root).
  system("/bin/bash"); //Execute a shell.
  return 0;
}

Then, after creating the script, we are going to do:

  1. Using gcc we will compile the code to convert it into an executable binary → gcc filename.c -o filename.
  2. Now, using chmod +s filename, we will assign SUID permission, which will make it execute as root.
  3. After that, we export the directory where the binary is located to the PATH → export PATH=<path_to_binary>:$PATH.
  4. Next, we include “/bin/bash” inside the binary in the PATH → echo "/bin/bash" > filename (if we have already done this previously, we can skip it) and we give it all permissions → chmod 777 filename.
  5. Finally, using ./filename, we execute the binary and escalate privileges.

Therefore, we do not need to search for binaries with SUID bit set, we can create a malicious file ourself, setting the SUID bit and using a malicious code (such as launch a reverse shell) to escalate privileges by executing a different command since it will be contained in the PATH environmental variable.

Practical Example:

We are going to proceed to perform a PATH Hijacking, to do this, first we are going to take a look at the PATH variable:

In this path, we can either drop a binary with SUID bit set (find / -perm -4000 -ls 2>/dev/null) or we can create a malicious file with SUID bit set (as we discussed earlier) in order to escalate privileges.

If we perform a search for binaries with SUID set, we find these files, but the one we are interested in is the last one which is located in the directory /home, specifically /home/murdoch/test.

Now, we are going to export this path to the PATH → *export PATH=/home/murdoch:$PATH* and if we run echo $PATH, we can see that it has changed:

Then, we change to file`s directory with SUID bit set → cd /home/murdoch/test and if we use cat on the file “tmh.py” we can display its content.

Where it says os.system("thm"), we need to replace ‘thm’ with ‘/bin/bash’, to do this, we use the command echo "/bin/bash" >> thm, we change all permissions to ‘all’, and then we execute it:

Finally, we see we have escalated privileges by doing a PATH Hijacking.

Privilege Escalation: NFS

Privilege escalation vectors are not only found in internal access, share files and remote management interfaces such as SSH or Telnet can also help us to gain root access on the target system.

The NFS (Network File Sharing) configuration is located in the file /etc/exports, which is created during the installation of the NFS server and can generally be read by system users.

If we run cat /etc/exports, we found information about the NFS configuration:

Here, the critical element is the option “no_root_squash” (as seen above).

When a client user accesses a shared directory or exported directory by the NFS server, the client’s permissions are mapped to the server’s permissions.

By default, NFS treats root users specially (for security reasons), where the option “root_squash” converts the root user into a normal user on the NFS server.

Therefore, if we find a shared directory without this configuration option, the NFS server allows users with root permissions on the client system to also have those permissions on the NFS server.

So, if this option (“no_root_squash”) is present on a shared resource and is writeable, we can create an executable with SUID bit set and execute it on the target system, giving us full control over the files and directories of the NFS server.

To achieve this, on the target machine we do the following:

  1. First of all, we are going to enumerate the mountable shares from out target machine → showmount -e <target_IP>
  2. We create a new mount one of the no_root_squash → mkdir /tmp/mount_name
  3. After that, we mount it → mount -o rw <our_IP>:/backups /tmp/mount_name
  4. Next, we write the malicious script on the share directory:
    We create this script in the C programming language, where we write the following:
    1. setgid(0) → We set the group ID to 0 (root).
    2. setuid(0) → We set the user ID to 0 (root).
    3. system("/bin/bash") → We launch a Bash shell.
    5. </li>
  5. Finally, we compile the script → gcc nfs.c -o nfs -w, and then we enable the SUID bit chmod +s nfs so that it can be executed as root.

Practical Example:

In this example we have a victim machine with the IP 10.10.58.32, where by using the command cat /etc/exports, we can see which directories are shared and contains the option “no_root_squash”.

As we can see above, there are several directory with this option enabled, so we can use any of them to gain access to the machine.

Since we want to share directory with the server that contains a malicious script, first we are going to enumerate the target`s machine shared directories.

Now, we are going to create a new directory (as root) in our directory /tmp, and then we will “share” this directory with one from the victim machine.

In this example, I selected the directory /home/ubuntu/sharedfolder because I can switch to that directory as non-root permission.

After sharing the directory, we are going to create a file with the extension .c (a script in the C programming language):

Inside the script, we write the following →

We create this script in C, where we do the following:

  1. setgid(0) → Set the group ID to 0 (root).
  2. setuid(0) → Set the user ID to 0 (root).
  3. system("/bin/bash") → Launch a Bash shell.

After writing the file with the .c extension, we need to convert into an executable. For this, we use the compiler gcc, which using the option -o file, converts the script into a binary with the same filename.

After obtaining the binary, we enable the SUID bit on it.

If we access the shared directory from the victim machine (in my case it is /home/ubuntu/sharedfolder, as I mentioned earlier) and if we list the contents using ls we can see both the file with .c extension and binary.

Finally, if we run the binary using ./eploit, we will see that a root shell is launched, meaning we will escalate privilege and become root user within the NFS server.

Capstone Challenge

The Capstone Challenge consists of a challenge proposed by the Lab, in which we must to obtain two flags. For this, we need to escalate privileges on a machine that we connect remotely via SSH.

First of all, we login using the following credentials leonard:Penny123 → ssh leonard@</code>

We are going to look for binaries with SUID bit set, so we will take advantage of this as it allows us in some scenarios to escalate privileges to root or execute commands without having the necessary permissions:

Bash 
find / -perm -4000 -ls 2>/dev/null

As we can see above, we found the binary base64 (which is the least common in this list), so we are going to try to exploit this binary to read some files, such as passwd and shadow (the latter requires root permissions to display its content).

We can look in GTFObins - Base64 to get information about how to execute the exploit.

Thanks to this, we can read the content of the shadow file without being root users.

Content of /etc/passwd file (system users):

Content of the /etc/shadow file (system passwords):

We are going to store both in these files respectively users.txt (for passwd) and pass.txt(for shadow) by copying their content from the legitimate file to ours.

Through the command unshadow, we combine both files into a new one called passwords.txt, which we will use to decrypt the hashed passwords.

After that, we use JohnTheRipper to decrypt these passwords by using a wordlist such as rockyou.txt:

We found a username missy and its password:

With these credentials, we are going to try to log into the server, and we will proceed to look for the flags:

We are in and we got the first flag, so now let’s figure out a way to escalate privileges to root.

For example, we are going to try running the command sudo -l for the user missy, to find out which commands can execute as root.

Indeed, we have found that we can make use of /usr/bin/find. As the escalation is a SUDO type will be only enough to execute this exploit in order to escalate privilege to root:

Bash 
sudo find . -exec /bin/sh \; -quit

Once we are root users, we perform a search for the second flag:

As a result, we obtained the second flag through privilege escalation using a command that the user missy can execute as root.
